key_points: Economics studies how individuals, businesses, and governments allocate resources to meet their needs and wants.
Microeconomics focuses on individual decision-making (e.g., supply and demand), while macroeconomics deals with large-scale economic factors like GDP, inflation, and unemployment.
Explains how the interaction between buyers and sellers determines prices. Example: As price decreases, demand increases (Law of Demand); as price increases, supply increases (Law of Supply).
The cost of choosing one option over another. Example: Choosing to study instead of working part-time.
Types include capitalism (market-driven), socialism (government regulates resources), and mixed economy (combination of both).
Measures the total value of goods and services produced within a country.
Inflation is an increase in prices over time (e.g., rising cost of groceries); unemployment rate is the percentage of jobless individuals actively seeking work.
Regulates markets, implements fiscal policies (government spending and taxation), and manages monetary policies to stabilize the economy.
